comment.author: 83040870@N06
comment._content: I'm curious, what are we looking at here?

comment.author: 49487266@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/83040870@N06] The original photo doesn't have any additional information besides a stamp of "Levassuer Edituer Photogrpahes Estampes Paris"

It might be an images of a captured German Airship in France...but that is just a guess
comment.authorname: San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives

comment.author: 83040870@N06
comment._content: It's obviously an exhibition of some sort. Too bad the placards aren't legible. Upon doing a little research I'm fairly convinced it's a Type Ae 800 Observation Balloon sans tail. See here: www.flickriver.com/photos/drakegoodman/4949466907/ www.allworldwars.com/The-German-Air-Force-In-The-Great-Wa... www.flickr.com/photos/drakegoodman/7073290633/in/set-7215... and www.flickr.com/photos/drakegoodman/5841448617/

comment.author: 48600072783@N01
comment._content: We are looking at the metallic structure of the Zeppelin L49 (Lz96), captured 1917/11/19 near Bourbonne-les-Bains. It is shown here in Paris, Jardin des Tuileries. Behind, it's a captive balloon (“saucisse”). L49 : www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/6871103279/ Autochrome version of the scene : albert-kahn.hauts-de-seine.net/fileadmin/images/Les_Archi... Other view : gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b53005657d
